Comments_List: This course teaches the foundations for international relations and new ways of thinking about human interactions and morals. The theories which are taught are practical in many ways, not just for this course. What you learn in this course will apply well beyond the limits of the classroom and truly give you a new perspective.

This course taught me how to really dig into different complexities, especially in morally grey areas. The course is centered around 6 different theoretical lenses and I appreciated that much of the semester was spent learning how to use them simultaneously. Professor Lyall's historical and chronological approach to international relations allowed us to learn that much of what we consider to be modern aspects of the world have really existed for thousands and thousands of years. We only got to World War II and the Cold War by spring break and the modern half of the course was just as complex and nuanced as the first. Professor Lyall also did a lot to project us forward and look at what future conflicts are potentially going to look like.

I loved this course! Prof. Lyall and the TFs were amazing! I learned not only about the theories behind international relations, but also current events. This class helped me to view history and policy in a new way.

Not anything I didn't have before. We learned about the study of international relations but not really any practical knowledge. I learned a little bit about certain issues because we discussed them as "international relations puzzles" and because we had to write papers, but nothing practical in class.
I learned about a topic I had never studied before and learned a lot

I learned so much about current affairs and past events through different theoretical lens that opened my eyes to so much information. Professor Lyall was beyond amazing. This class practically made me change my major to political science.

This course was incredible. It taught me everything from overall historical analysis, to new perspectives on looking at current and past events, to learning how to read scholarly articles. I learned how to discuss topics in international relations, how to consider new perspectives and ideas and possibilities on events that I already new about, and I learned about topics that I hadn't known about before. Because of the high amount of reading, I also improved my reading and writing skills, and my overall ability to do analysis in a class setting.

This course is taught by an amazing professor and the TA's for the class do their job so well. The lectures are engaging and on extremely interesting topics and section with my TA complemented the lectures perfectly. Every aspect of the course is paced perfectly and organized in a logical manner. Though the readings can be bit heavy at the beginning of the course, but the content learned through them is extremely valuable and they are amazing resources when completing the assignments. There are no weaknesses to this course as long as you keep up on the readings.

The strengths of this course were really professor Lyall. He was an incredible lecturer and pulled us all into a lecture despite the fact that it was a relatively large lecture and classroom. He was clearly so passionate about what we were learning and also about us as students and our understanding. We had a lecture about 2/3 through the semester where we had a class-wide debate about whether or not US actions in Iraq could be considered a war crime. He was always very careful to make sure that he was presenting the information as objectively as possible, never revealing his preferences for certain explanations than others.
The course is very well structured, and I thoroughly enjoyed it. The only weakness is that Prof. Lyall won't be teaching it next time.

Jason Lyall is an amazing professor and engaging lecturer, and it's a real shame that he's not going to be here anymore. I thought it was taught well and the TA's were all great. That said, I didn't really gain any practical knowledge from the course, but that's also because you're not supposed to be because it's ~theoretical~. The readings were engaging but nothing that was a pain to get through (my TA split up the readings in session so I never had to do all of them-- if I had, it would've been a pain).
I believe there's way too much assigned for this class. Sometimes up to 150 pages a week of academic reading is very tough especially when you have a full schedule.

A weakness is that the reading assigned is A LOT (100-150 pgs between classes at times), which makes it difficult to fully comprehend each text and give it the attention it deserves. However, a strength is that the lecturer, Jason Lyall, is absolutely amazing and makes the lectures incredibly interesting on a daily basis.

Strengths: The TAs, professor, and content was amazing. It was presented clearly, efficiently, and in an overall unbiased way. It helped me formulate my own opinions and ideas about the content. 

Weaknesses: Lots of readings!
Great course

The professor is an amazing teacher. Makes lectures fun and enjoyable.

AMAZING TAKE THIS

Lessen the amount of readings, otherwise everything else was very strong like both the lectures and the sections were taught very well and I absorbed a lot of the information

weaknesses: sometimes section wasn't well structured and I wish it was rooted in discussing the readings more which would have been helpful for the final, too  many readings for sure

The greatest strength of this course was the lecturer, Professor Jason Lyall, and I think its an absolute shame that this incredibly talented and valued professor was denied tenure. I guarantee that the students are upset by this decision by Yale.
Sections lacked any particular structure, but TAs did a great job of reviewing material covered in lecture and the main ideas/takeaways of some of the important course readings.
Loved it! Course was extremely well organized and taught.

Strengths: Lectures are pretty good, although would benefit from student engagement. Readings are difficult but rewarding, and well chosen to illustrate the differences of opinion that constitute international relations. Weaknesses: I think using the lenses (realism, rationalism, constructivism, etc.) is a great way to introduce students to the debates in IR, but both lecture and section tended to oversimplify things just so every subject would fit neatly into the different IR lenses. Almost nothing we learned could fit neatly into five discrete boxes of thought, but that was how they were portrayed. I think the course could have included a little more on genocide and migration, but that's just me. Finally, my TA was stunningly unhelpful. He didn't facilitate a very engaging section, and his feedback on my papers was like he hadn't even read them.

That said, this was not your average introductory International Relations class, and the more traditional course taught by a more traditional instructor would have never been as engaging or life changing.

Honestly don't waste your time with this class. There is a lot of clout associated with the lecture and it really is not worth it, take some other poli sci class that will give you more than just a basic summary of already well known historic events.  Readings are extremely numerous and you honestly need to do all of them to stay up to date for sections and to understand what's happening.  Expect to spend many hours every week just trying to understand the readings and theories, especially the first half of the semester.  The sections ran vary autonomously to the lecture, and oftentimes I felt like the section was not even following the ideas from lecture.  The expectations are also high, but that could just be my TF who was very unclear with expectations, grading, etc. The final exam was absolutely beyond excessive, in the sense that you had to prepare for triple the number of essays actually to be written (outline 12 essays to write about 3) and then you essentially just recite your outlines and hope you incorporate enough readings, insights, etc.  The class caused way more stress than necessary, was not well organized, and not worth my time nor yours.
I would recommend this class for its content, as it is interesting and engaging, and the format, as two papers and two exams is relatively manageable, but the reading is big turn off.
